title: Read Classical Passages with Verb Forms
instruction: Translate these passages from classical Buddhist texts. Identify the verb stems and their tenses to understand the meaning.

questions.title: From the Heart Sutra
questions.transliteration: spyan ras gzigs dbang phyug gis shes rab kyi pha rol tu phyin pa zab mo spyad pa'i tshe / phung po lnga po de dag stong par bltas so
questions.questionPrompt: Translate this opening passage of the Heart Sutra. Identify the two past-tense verbs.
questions.correctAnswer: When Noble Avalokiteshvara was practicing the profound Perfection of Wisdom, he saw that the five aggregates are empty.
questions.analysis: Two past stems: སྤྱད (practiced — past of སྤྱོད) and བལྟས (saw — past of བལྟ). སྤྱད་པའི་ཚེ means 'at the time of practicing'. བལྟས་སོ has the sentence-final particle སོ. Subject: སྤྱན་རས་གཟིགས་དབང་ཕྱུག (Noble Avalokiteshvara).

questions.title: From Samantabhadra's Aspiration Prayer
questions.transliteration: bdag gis 'gro ba kun gyi don du dge ba thams cad byang chub tu bsngo
questions.questionPrompt: Translate this dedication verse. What tense is the verb and why?
questions.correctAnswer: I shall dedicate all virtue toward enlightenment for the benefit of all beings.
questions.analysis: བསྔོ is the future stem of སྔོ (to dedicate) — expressing aspiration. Key particles: གྱི (genitive — 'of'), དོན་དུ (for the purpose of), ཏུ (terminative — 'toward'). This verse combines case particles from Lesson 2 with the future tense from Lesson 3.

correctFeedback: Excellent comprehension! You understand verb tenses in classical Buddhist passages.
incorrectFeedback: Review the passage carefully. Look for the verb at the end and identify its stem to determine the tense.
